snippet: Millions of Americans have trained for new careers through the $3.1 billion Workforce Investment Act, but many have not found new jobs and are instead faced with thousands of dollars of debt.
abstract: Many of the millions of Americans who have enrolled in vocational training through the Workforce Investment Act have wound up significantly worse off, accumulating debt and failing to land a new job; $3.1 billion program was created following the financial crisis, and was renewed by Congress with little public discussion of its effectiveness; analysis has shown chief flaws include lack of oversight and reliance on expensive, for-profit institutions.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans have trained for new careers through the $3.1 billion Workforce Investment Act, but many have not found new jobs and are instead faced with thousands of dollars of debt.

headline.seo: Workforce Investment Act Leaves Many Jobless and in Debt
headline.main: Seeking New Start, Finding Steep Cost
